importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding occurred last week, with the death toll and missing persons reported in the context of that time period, establishing the timeline of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding affecting five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing, with confirmed deaths in Veracruz (29), Hidalgo (21), Puebla (13), and Queretaro (1).
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.

Thousands of military troops—including the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard—have been deployed to assist affected areas, delivering food, clean water, and emergency supplies via air and ground operations.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rise, landslides, and significant damage.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Approximately 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply to the five states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating such heavy rainfall, raising concerns about Mexico’s early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused severe flooding and landslides across five Mexican states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The worst-hit areas include Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, which received over 280mm of rain. The government deployed thousands of military personnel and emergency workers to deliver food, clean water, and restore critical infrastructure, including power. Despite significant damage, about 80% of electricity has been restored. President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua highlighted the absence of prior meteorological warnings, raising questions about the effectiveness of Mexico’s early alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
